qas.question: When was the Silurian period believed to have begun?
Compared to the Ordovician glaciation, how big were the ice caps on Gondwana during the Silurian?
What did the melting of ice on Gondwana add to?
Which supercontinent formed during the Silurian?
Which ocean ranged the majority of the northern hemisphere in the Silurian period?
What continent continued to drift northward during the Silurian?
What was more extensive compared to the Ordovician glaciations?

plausible_answers.text: The melting of ice caps and glaciers

qas.question: What lead to a rise in sea levels during the Ordovician?
what was formed from Euramerica breaking up?
What large ocean covered most of the Southern hemisphere?

context: The Silurian is a major division of the geologic timescale that started about <a0_0>443.8 ± 1.5 Ma.<a0_0/> During the Silurian, <b5_0>Gondwana<b5_0/> continued a slow southward drift to high southern latitudes, but there is evidence that the <b6_0>Silurian ice caps<b6_0/> were <a1_0>less extensive<a1_0/> than those of the late Ordovician glaciation. <b7_0>The melting of ice caps and glaciers<b7_0/> contributed to <a2_0>a rise in sea levels<a2_0/>, recognizable from the fact that Silurian sediments overlie eroded Ordovician sediments, forming an unconformity. Other <b8_0>cratons and continent fragments<b8_0/> drifted together near the equator, starting the formation of a second supercontinent known as <a3_0>Euramerica<a3_0/>. The vast ocean of <a4_0><b9_0>Panthalassa<b9_0/><a4_0/> covered most of the northern hemisphere. Other minor oceans include Proto-Tethys, Paleo-Tethys, Rheic Ocean, a seaway of Iapetus Ocean (now in between Avalonia and Laurentia), and newly formed Ural Ocean.
